Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Expectation2: Coordinate with other air traffic controllers to ensure smooth traffic flow
Situation2: One aircraft is about to cross into the neighboring sector on a normal route.
Story: My phone buzzes on the console, a text from my stepdad: “Hope you’re having a good weekend. Let us know you’re okay.” I glance at it, guilt prickling. I haven’t checked in since last Sunday, and I know my mom worries if I go quiet. But right now, my headset crackles with the voice of a pilot requesting clearance to cross into the next sector. I need to coordinate with the controller on the other side, double-check the flight path, and make sure there’s no conflict. My supervisor expects flawless communication—one mistake could mean disaster. My stepdad’s message sits unread, a reminder of the promise I made to keep in touch, to be present for my family even if I’m not living at home. I feel the weight of both worlds pressing in: the responsibility to keep hundreds of lives safe in the sky, and the quieter, persistent pull to reassure the people who raised me that I’m still part of their lives. My fingers hover over my phone, my other hand gripping the radio, torn between two voices calling for my attention.
